item.description:
From the publisher’s website:

Ready...Aim...Crossfire! Can you handle your next mission in the Surge Strike Arena? Blast away with your B-Daman figure (figures sold separately) and try to lock three or more bars in the arena before your opponent does. Do you have what it takes for precision target blasting? Find out with the Surge Strike Arena. Surge Strike Arena includes a centerpiece with five Surge Strike bars. Fire at the centerpiece and lock 3 bars before your opponent does. Includes unassembled arena, 6 B-DA Marbles, collector card, label sheet, and instructions.

From the publisher’s website:

Ready…Aim…Crossfire! Can you handle your next mission in the Vertigo Spin Arena? Blast away with your B-Daman figure (figures sold separately) and try to knock three marbles out of the arena before your opponent does. Do you have what it takes for precision target blasting? Find out with the Vertigo Spin Arena. Vertigo Spin Arena includes a centerpiece with six Vertigo Spin marble slots! Fire at the centerpiece and knock three marbles out before your opponent does. Includes unassembled arena, 6 B-DA Marbles, collector card, label sheet, and instructions.

Arbalester is a medieval battle game for 2, 3 or 4 players. Mixing wargame and strategy, the player has at his hands an army with wich should eliminate all enemies.

To compose the army, the player can choose from 7 kinds of soldiers. Each class has certain range of attack, life points and special abilities. Simply, move with two dices and attack with one, but complex too, the player can combine their soldiers for over 100 different army combinations.

The board is divided into squares, as in Stratego.

Turns are alternative, one player moves and attacks with his army in his turn and when it finish, take certain cards.
Cards may be of many types (objects, siege weapons, terrain, etc)and provide variety and duration to the game.

Spanish description:
Arbalester es un juego de batallas medievales para 2, 3 o 4 jugadores. Mezcla de Wargame y juego de estrategia, el jugador tiene a su disposición un ejército con el que deberá eliminar a todos sus enemigos.
Para componer el ejército, el jugador puede elegir entre 7 clases de soldados. Cada clase tiene cierto rango de ataque, puntos de vida y habilidades especiales. El jugador podrá combinar los soldados según su estrategia existiendo más de 100 combinaciones distintas.
El tablero se divide en casillas cuadradas, como en el Stratego. Para el movimiento se usan dos dados y para el ataque un dado. Los turnos son alternativos, cada jugador mueve y ataca con todo su ejército en su turno y al finalizarlo, coge ciertas cartas.
Las cartas pueden ser de muchos tipos y aportan variedad y duración al juego. Pueden aparecer objetos, armas de asedio, tipos de terreno, etc.

item.description:
The Lamps Are Going Out is a fast-paced game of strategic decision making in the First World War for two to four players.

There are two Alliances – Central Powers and Triple Entente – each divided into two Factions. The Central Powers player controls the Germany and Central Allies (Austria-Hungary, Turkey and Bulgaria) Factions while the Triple Entente player has the Western Allies (Great Britain, Belgium, France and Italy) and Eastern Allies/US (Russia, Serbia, Romania and United States) Factions.

A game turn consists of:
Event Card Phase
Movement Phase (up to two units may be moved)
Combat Phase (cards are played to support combat)
Production Phase (players spend production points to rally armies, invest in new technology, or lend points to other players)

Players must make critical decisions each turn as to how to spend their scarce resources. Production Points are required to Refit spent units, build new units, construct trenches, conduct research, etc. The combat system is very simple, but yields tremendous excitement and that “just one more attack should do it” feeling. Event cards allow for all sorts of historical situations, conditions, leaders, political events and so on. Everything that would be important in a WWI simulation is considered in this game.

name.value: The Last Stand: Little Big Horn June 25, 1876

item.description:
The Last Stand: Little Big Horn June 25, 1876 is a low complexity solitaire wargame on the Battle of the Little Big Horn or Custer's Last Stand.

A game turn consists of:
Encampment Activation (Activating Native American units)
Movement
Offensive Fire
Defensive Fire
Rush Combat
Rally

The player controls US Seventh Cavalry under General Custer. Native American units are activated as the player approaches them. The game system controls their movement and combat. Each unit has a combat strength (CEF value), firing range, and movement ability.

The player wins if he or she can control a tribal hex for a full turn. The player loses if more than 20 CEF points in the game.

The game includes several alternative history scenarios that explore the possibility of the day's events going differently. For example, in one scenario, Benteen's Battalion arrives earlier to aid 7th Cavalry. In another, the player has access to a Gatling Gun that never made it to the actual battle.

The game is available in boxed, folio, or PNP formats.

name.value: Farmers vs Empire: The Second Boer War & Bloody veld – battle of Magersfontein, 11 December, 1899

item.description:
Two wargames in one box.

				
					The Second Boer War 1899-1902 (a strategic wargame).

Game description
The game presents the struggles that took place during the Second Boer War between 1899 - 1902. The game consists of four phases, each of which is divided into 22 rounds. During rounds, players perform certain actions. The first and second phase of the game reflect the regular phase of the war. The third and fourth phases are constructed differently, because they represent a specific phase of guerrilla warfare.

The game uses the point to point system, six-sided dice and a deck of battle cards. The game map represents Cape Colony, Natal, Orange Free State and Republic of Transval. Each game phase corresponds to 3-9 months of real time. Military units (infantry, cavalry, artillery, tribals, machine guns, trains) are represented by abstract battle cards.
During the game the players will carry out a series of operations (move, fight, events, special actions) using random actions (1 to 3 on the turn of the game).
The introduced game events directly relate to historical events, directing the moves of players during the game.

Battle cards are used to resolve combat in situations when contact between commanders of military formations is established. In "The Second Boer War 1899 - 1902" the military units involved in the combat are presented on cards. Depending on the phase of the game or the commander involved the combat may be a battle or a skirmish.
During the battle, players use six cards, although this number may be increased with the rules on the Boer trenches or British garrisons. Individual characteristics of commanders are also important.
The British player can choose the cards that he intends to use in battle, but the Boer player draws them randomly – this describes the voluntary nature of the Boer army.
The battlefield is divided into three sections - the right wing, the left wing and the center.
The Defender begins the battle and places one card on each section. Then the attacker puts two cards for each section and performs troop morale checks. If the check fails, the card does not participate in the battle.
Defender reveals the cards and adds one to each section, testing their morale. If players have a surplus of cards, they can use them on the sections of the battlefield, where there are less than two cards.
Players compare their strength for each section. The player who achieved 2 or 3 successes, wins the battle. The opponent suffers losses - British cards goes into the reinforcements pool, and the Boer commandos cards are eliminated.

A skirmish is a smaller combat – the card limit is 3, but can be increased by the individual characteristics of the commander, the Boer fortifications or British garrisons. The British player can choose the cards he will use in a skirmish. The Boer player can choose one card, but he must randomly draw the other.
The Defender places one card on each section of the battlefield. Then the Attacker does the same thing. For each card, he performs morale checks – a negative result means that the unit is not taking part in the skirmish, and can be replaced with a card from the surplus, if the player has it.
Both players add the “Strength” value of their cards. The winner of the skirmish is the player, who achieved a higher score. If the loser is the Defender, he must vacate the occupied area.

				
					Bloody veld: Battle of Magersfontein, 11 December, 1899 (a tactical wargame).

Game scale:
1 hex = 500 yd (457 m)
1 game turn = 45 minutes
1 counter = British infantry half battalion or part of Boer commando/cavalry regiment/artillery battery (Boer army: 1 gun).

Game description
The game uses the standard hex-and-counter system, and ten-sided dice. Each hex represents 500 yards or 457 metres, each game turn corresponds to 45 minutes of real time.
British infantry is represented by half battalions, cavalry by regiments, artillery by batteries. One counters represents a part of a commando or one gun.

Each game turn is divided into phases:
1) Command phase – players use their Commanders-in-Chief and dispatch riders to give orders to subordinate commanders,
2) Activation phase – after determining the initiative, players, using the Activation Markers, choose the brigade to activate. Activated units, move, fire, commence melee combat (only British units) and reorganize units and recover morale. The opponent can react by firing or counterattacking (only British units),
3) Reorganization phase – players reorganize broken units.
The principle of the game is based on an order system, which is associated with an action vector. The player must carry out the assigned order (of course, he gives them to himself), until the order is changed by the Commander-in-Chief, or the brigade commander manages to change it by himself. The order must be associated with a target hex (i.e attack hex, defend hex). The possible orders are: ATTACK or DEFEND.

The game tries to present the diversity of combatants tactics mainly through unit formations. 
British units may perform weapon attacks and melee attacks. Boer units can only fire, but they start the game masked, moreover, some of them can benefit from the trenches. It makes it difficult for the British player who cannot shoot at masked units from a larger distance. The fieldworks allow the Boers to minimize their losses.

The game treats the concept of zone of control differently from other games – it gives up the obligation to stop moving the unit in the enemy ZOC. The ZOC is a phenomenon that allows to fire or initiate close combat, and it is dependent on the units formation and the range of its firearms.
Unit movement doesn’t differ from other hex-and-counter systems.

Fire combat takes into account the distance to the target, the firing unit morale and terrain on which the target is currently placed. Artillery performs its fire in the same way, using another fire combat chart. Distinct units are the Boer Pom-Pom automatic guns. These cannons move like artillery, but actually perform their fire according to the infantry fire chart. Each shot, however, means performing two checks and summing the results of fire. The result of fire combat can be the loss of morale, combat efficiency level or routing. Additionally also withdrawal.

Melee combat is also based on the unit’s morale, strength, formation, also the terrain. The effects of melee combat are almost the same as the effects of fire combat. The exception being the possibility of forcing the enemy to flee. Cavalry combat also includes the unit’s momentum. Cavalry may react by counter-charging.
The loss of unit’s morale endurance during the game is marked with special markers.

Spanish Trivial clone with striptease theme. 
2-6 players.
Cheap materials.

This is a social party game designed to create moments of fun interaction within a group.

To start a game each player is dealt 8 Quote Cards. One player is selected to be the “historian” for the round and plays a History Card from the deck. Each player finishes the quote by passing one Quote Card face down to the historian. The historian for each round does not play a card. The historian shuffles the answers, reads them out loud in context with the History Card, and picks their favorite combination (usually the one that got the most laughs). Whoever played the chosen Quote Card gets to keep the History Card as a point.

At the beginning of each round select a new “historian” by moving clockwise around the room. Also, every player should draw a new card to bring their card total back to eight cards. The game is played until a pre-determined amount of points are earned by a single player (typically five).

Dogs In The Yard is a tile laying game for 2 to 6 players. It's a game of both chance and strategy, where you and your opponents take turns drawing tiles to build out a map one tile at a time with grass and fences, and try to construct yards around dogs to earn points. They also have to make sure their dogs are fed and watered, and can get extra points with toys and treats.

Can you keep a straight face - even when you're lying? Can you tell the difference between a truth and a blatant bluff?

If you're the world's best blagger, or just a champion cheater, then this is the game for you. thinking on your feet and coming up with creative answers are what counts here - and you'll need to reel off some real-sounding suggestions if you want to win. Players must come up with - and pass off - plausible meanings for words and sayings in 4 different rounds including word definitions; sayings; world customs and moments in history, but only one of them will be genuine. Can you fish out the red herrings and spot which one?

name.value: Dale of Merchants Het gilde van de buitengewone handelaren
Dale of Merchants: The Guild of Extraordinary Traders
Tal der Kaufleute: Die Gilde der außergewöhnlichen Händler
la Vallée des Marchands: la Guilde des Commerçants Extraordinaires

item.description:
It is an age of great discoveries. New and wonderful items find their ways into the hands of the greatest merchants. And if there ever is a place those traders love, it is the town of Dale.

There’s an extraordinary guild in the Dale founded by the greatest merchants. The tricky part is getting the membership since one must win the annual trading competition to be invited to the guild.

Notable animalfolk merchants from all over the world have gathered in the town to take part in the event. Everyone has only one goal in mind – to be celebrated as the winner and the newest member of the legendary guild.

In Dale of Merchants, players take the roles of those participating merchants learning new techniques, trading goods, and managing their stock. The player who first manages to complete their astounding merchant stall wins the game and gets access to the guild!

link.value: Dale of Merchants: Systematic Eurasian Beavers

item.description:
A card game inspired by the Potato Salad Kickstarter project, personally approved by Zack Danger Brown.

Players compete to be the first to gather all the ingredients to one of four potato salad recipes. You can acquire ingredients by drawing them from the deck, purchasing them from cards on the table or in the discards, or trading with other players.

Automotive Annihilation is a car racing and combat game; the core mechanics are rolling five custom dice, moving around a board, and playing weapon cards. It has several unique features that separate it from similar themed games including a lane changing mechanic where you cannot pass cars that are in your lane. The dice rolling is similar to King of Tokyo.

Automotive Annihilation will appeal greatly to hardcore gamers while being accessible and easy to learn and play for almost anybody

Clockwork Armada is a naval miniatures game set in an alternate reality of flat worlds and pseudoscience, where ships sail on the upward rushing winds of space.

Each player takes command of a fleet of warships from their chosen faction, choosing what specialized cruisers and escort squadrons to combine into a synergistic force. A unique flagship is chosen to lead each armada, providing it with special Directives to enhance the abilities of nearby ships.

A game of Clockwork Armada plays out in a continual rotation of alternating activations. Ships will board, ram, and fire at each other, using stat cards to keep track of the damage done to the different areas of a ship. A set of segmented Course Rulers is used to determine the maneuverability of lumbering capital ships and nimble corvettes.

A shared mission and individual objectives give each player multiple means of scoring enough victory points to win the game.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Adelaide, Australia.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Zwickau, Germany. There are also - additionally/separately - 8 'typical' Zwickau pawns available.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Inditex, a fashion retail group.

The bee game consists of 32 playing cards and is adapted for 2 - 5 players. The goal of the game is to dispose of all your cards by attaching them to the already existing honeycombs. When doing this, at least two sides of the cards must be attached and the bees must be put together correctly.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Firefly.

Description from the publisher:

Zombicide: Black Plague takes the zombie apocalypse into a fantastical medieval setting! The arcane powers of the Necromancers have unleashed a zombie invasion in the age of swords and sorcery, and it's up to your group of straggling survivors to not only stay alive during these dark times, but to take back the realm and punish those responsible for the apocalypse!

Zombicide: Black Plague allows you take control of paladins, dwarves, knights, and magicians, wielding powerful swords, crossbows, and even magic spells to defeat the zombie hordes and its Necromancer overlords. The classic Zombicide rules have been revamped for this new incarnation of the game, while still retaining the nonstop action, tense atmosphere and easy-to-learn rules that made Zombicide a classic. Equip your survivor with equipment like chainmail armor or shields to defend against the undead, pick up spell books to perform fantastic enchantments, or light up a pool of dragon bile to create an all-consuming inferno of dragon fire!

Take on the zombie invasion from the medieval streets to secret vaults that create quick passages through the citadel (and often hold special artifacts). Chase down the elusive Necromancers to keep them from multiplying the zombie masses. And tackle a whole new set of missions through which your group of survivors will become the heroes of the land (or the last victims of the zombie massacre).

item.description:
Ocean Labyrinth uses the same basic game play as Ravensburger's decades-old title The aMAZEing Labyrinth. Players try to move through a labyrinthine game board in order to reach a desired symbol shown on a game board tile that matches a hidden card held by this player. The game board consists of a number of fixed tiles as well as rows and columns in which tiles can slide back and forth; these tiles show tunnels – T-shaped, straight, and otherwise – and a player can move his token only along the path as it exists on his turn.

At the start of his turn, however, he takes the one tile on the side of the game board and pushes it into a row or column of his choice, shifting the tunnels and pushing out one tile that the next player will use. This player now moves his pawn, and if he reaches the desired symbol, he reveals the card, then looks at the next card in his stack to see what he wants to reach next turn. Once a player has revealed all of his cards, he needs to return to his starting corner. The first player to do this wins!

To this basic game, Ocean Labyrinth adds an underwater theme and a twist: some tiles have special rules on their backsides. When a tile of this type is pushed out, a special rule is used for the next turn:


 Pufferfish: the current player is so scared from this fish that they lose their movement for the current turn.
 Diving scooter: you move more quickly: take an additional turn
 Oxygen tank: you don't have enough oxygen, so you must return your pawn to a freely chosen start tile.

item.description:
Galaxy Zento is a game in which players choose to be good or evil, become a player character type at random, and must be first to obtain a randomly issued goal to win.

Players take turns in movement on the board. Each move causes a card to be revealed from the top of the main deck. Players face characters, creatures, and traps, but also obtain rewards and character building cards to make them stronger.

The game employs a d20 system for combat and other card tasks.

Galaxy Zento: Chessmen is based on the fantasy novel, Chessmen: Opening Moves. Galaxy Zento is a complete universe of adventure.

name.value: Monopoly: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back

item.description:
Bring the magic of the movies home with the first board game ever based on the films of Kevin Smith!

The cross-country adventure of "Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back" is now an official, authorized edition of Monopoly, with a game board featuring art and locations from the movie! The game also has new Chance cards, Community Chest cards and game pieces, all set to the same classic Monopoly gameplay! Packaged in a full-color game box with movie artwork.

A Diamond Select Toys release
 The first board game ever based on the films of Kevin Smith
 Based on the cult favorite film
 An official, authorized edition of Monopoly
 Game board features art and locations from the movie

Shapes & Stuff is a tile laying game for two players. The aim of the game is to build shapes by connecting your colour’s dots using two or more tiles in the effort to beat your opponent in a “tug-o-war” of points.

Barricado is an abstract strategy game of tile placement and area control. Each turn, players choose between influence over the board (by placing a tile) or claiming territory upon it (by building barricades). Barricades can be extended but never crossed. The player with the most barricade segments on the board at game’s end wins.

The layout is always different, and the tactics often varied, as every turn poses new challenges and opportunities. Will you be the one that gets painted into a corner, or will you claim total control of the streets?

Mash the buttns along with your opponents in this exciting 2-4 player dice game that emulates playing an old school fighting game!

Do you remember the glory days of arcades; walking into that dimly lit building, the buzzing lights and distractingly repetitive tunes fighting one another, vying for your attention? I recall fondly how my shoes fought for every step as the floor clung stickily to them and feeding my quarter into the arcade machine only to watch it disappear and the machine not reading it. Do you recall the days of getting really good at your favorite game and taking on any challenger; and then getting destroyed by that one person who didn’t know what they were doing, and kept hitting the same button over and over again? Well ... welcome to Button Mashers!

Button Mashers is a 2-4 player dice game where players take turns rolling dice, and match the results to their character's special moves to deal damage to their opponent

Oolong is a strategy game of area control for two players. Take turns serving tea to tables in the tea house in an attempt to serve more of your tea than your opponent. Your turn consists of simply placing a token on a tile, but your play tells your opponent where they’re allowed to play next. Controlling a tile will trigger that table’s special of the day, a unique one-time ability. Will you be shrewd enough to fully serve the most tables and savor sweet victory?

The 9 tiles are arranged like the points of a compass rose (plus the center). Players take turns placing a token of their color. The space in which a token is placed indicates the tile on which the next player will place their token. The player who is first to occupy 5 spaces on a tile controls that tile. Unique special abilities for each tile are triggered at different levels of completeness. Whomever is first to control 5 tiles wins.

The war is over, and the Greek ships are trying to return to their homeland after a long absence. They need to reach the Sacred Island to present offerings and prayers to the gods, but the irascible Poseidon will use all his power to prevent them from getting there.

In Odyssey: Wrath of Poseidon, one player takes the role of Poseidon, God of the Sea, while the others become navigators in search of the Sacred Island. Gameplay takes place on two copies of the same game board that are separated by the game box so that they are not visible to one another. The Poseidon player throws powerful storms against the Navigators, driving them off-course and confounding them so that they cannot reach the Sacred Island in time. Only Poseidon knows the real position of the ships as indicated on his copy of the game board.

The navigators must sail through endless storms, blind to all around them, trying to gather clues to their whereabouts to stay on course. They also track the position of their ships on the game board, but the positions indicated are only a best guess — and they can become increasingly inaccurate as the game progresses.

The navigators must use their wits to stay on course and reach the Sacred Island before the end of the game, while Poseidon wins by preventing them from reaching their destination.

item.description:
Pharaoh needs his newest pyramid to be built, and he turns to you, the various government contractors and architects to help him build it. Each player bids secretly the amount that they would pay Pharaoh to build his pyramid. The winner then gets to try to build the next block in Pharaoh's pyramid. As a reward for building each block, you will receive some of Pharaoh's valuable gold. The player with the most gold in the end wins!

It is challenging to build Pharaoh's pyramid because you have to pay to supply enough people and resources to build each block. But that is left to chance. Each player determines how much they would like to spend on their roll, but they only get one opportunity to succeed.

The game is broken down into levels, rounds, and stages. There are three levels in the game, one for each layer of the pyramid. As the pyramid gets taller, the game gets more challenging. Each level is broken into rounds, one block is built each round. Will you end with the most of Pharaoh's gold?

name.value: Tides of Time: Im Strom der Zeit
Tides of Time: Le Maree del Tempo

item.description:
Play as an ancient civilization as they prosper and collapse through time. Build gigantic monuments, raise impenetrable fortifications, and amass vast knowledge as the ages pass. The greatest civilizations will leave their mark long after their collapse. From times long forgotten to times recently lost, civilizations will rise and fall as the tide of time carries them.

Tides of Time is a drafting game for two players. Each game consists of three rounds in which players draft cards from their hands to build their kingdom. Each card is one of five suits and also has a scoring objective. After all cards have been drafted for the round, players total their points based on the suits of cards they collected and the scoring objectives on each card, then they record their score. Each round, the players each select one card to leave in their kingdom as a "relic of the past" to help them in later rounds. After three rounds, the player with the the most prosperous kingdom wins.

item.description:
Moments Card Game is a solo or multi-player game that let the player decide the events that will occur in their lifetime. Players must choose their actions and decide the use of their time. Players are given different choices represented by different types of cards and time pieces to play these actions. Players go through the game choosing their own path. They can get an education, start a career or business, seek adventure, focus on art and music, seeks happiness through health/fitness or humor. The objective of the game is to score the most points before time runs out. Players acquire skills, make friend/partners and collect moments to score points.

Gameplay

The objective of the game is to collect points and capture moments in life before time runs out. Each player receives 12 physical time pieces. The time pieces can be used for actions, gain skills, or make friends.

There are 7 types of cards:

Moments Cards: (Worth 2 or 3 points)

You need a specific skill or or attribute, use an action card or hosts event to capture the Moment card.
For example: The Graduation moments card can be scored with two education skills.

Skills/ Education card: (Worth 1 point)

You will need to spend time pieces to acquire skills. This card is a permanent gained card that you place in front of you.

For example: The music skill card can be acquired with two time pieces.

Friend/ Partner card: (Worth 1 or 2 points)

You will need to spend one time piece to gain a friend. You will need to have the same skill or interest to gain a partner. This card is placed in the center when it is a friend. Another player can also be their friend. Players can gain a partner after they are friends. Partners are placed in front of the player. Player acquire the partner's skills.

For example: The Audrey friend card can be gain as a friend using one time piece. In order to make Audrey a partner, you would need to have the music skill or money or use a music or money action card.

Action card: (No points)

You will need one time piece to use the action card. However, action card can only be used once and can be used with any other cards.

For example: The graduation moments card can be scored by using a education action card if the player already acquired an education skill card. Players can use an education action card

Event card: (No Points)

You will need to have the skills of the event to use this card. You can have the skills, use an action card, use a partner's skill to score the event for yourself. You can also use other player's skills to hosts this event. The other player will be invited to the event and can score moments card as well. Event can score moments cards with event icons.

For example: The Musical festival event card can be scored with professional skill, music skill, and money. Players that attended the event can score a moments card that require an event.

Time card: (Gain two time pieces)

You will need to have the skills of the time card to use this card. This card is a one time use card and players can gain time pieces if they score this card.

For Example: the start new company time card can be used if player have the music, humor/happiness and the money attributes. People will gain two time pieces.

Situation Card: (Minus time pieces)

If players draw situation cards, all players must lose time pieces.

Goal of the game is to score the most points are the end of the game.

Follow Star Girl and her group of friends on their adventures through the galaxies, in search of ancient alien artifacts and help them fight the Evil Space Queen!

Star Girl is a quick take-that card game for 2-5 players using just 24 cards.

The game is played in a series of rounds. 
Rounds consist of players taking turns in clockwise order.

Taking a turn:
Draw a card from the Deck (You will then have 2 cards in your hand)
2. Play a card and apply its effect
3. Pass play to the next player

End of a Round:
The round ends when there are no more cards in the Deck or when there is only a single player left and all others have been knocked out (Players will be knocked out by the effects of some cards).

Winning a round:
You can win a round in 2 different ways:

 (Be the only player still in the round (the other players need to be „out of the round“)
 Have the lowest ranked card in your hand of all players still in the round.




Winning the game:
You can either play the game as a single round or a series of rounds.

In this game of bluffing and deception, players try to gain influence over the different factions of the Dune universe.
These factions (The Bene Gesserit, Fremen, Bene Tleilax, Ix, Sardaukar, Mentats, Suk doctors, Landsraad and Spacing Guild) are represented by face down cards, of which each player is dealt 2 at the start of the game and which give access to special actions.

Dune: The Art of Kanly is played out in a sequence of turns in which players use these special actions by claiming to have the necessary face down faction cards (This claim needn't be truthful and players can "bluff" ownership of any card they wish to use). The claims may in return be challenged by other players and some actions may also be countered. Players whose bluffs are revealed or players who falsely accuse another player of bluffing pay a penalty.

The game is won by either being the last player to have any face down cards or to be the first player to own 13 Spice.

In a special turn of events players may also negotiate for a shared victory using an "allied victory" ability available to all players.

This is a simple roll-and-move game. The first player to reach the circus, wins the game.

The game was published as a program booklet for a children's varieté.

Mixtape Massacre is a tabletop board game where up to 6 people play as horror film archetypes and compete in a fictional 1986 killing spree to be remembered.

Players travel the streets of Tall Oaks visiting different town locations, vying for a chance to draw a card from the "Killer Scenes, Dude" deck (cards decorated like VHS tapes of old), providing an opportunity to slay victims and collect souvenirs. Claim your prize by rolling the action dice marked in knives, fists, and pentagrams to the amount required on your card.

Along the way, take your chances with the "Bonus Tracks" cards (decorated like your favorite dusty mixtape) or engage in Brawls, where players can battle it out and eliminate one another from the game. To win the game, be the first to rack up a body count of 10 or be the last player left alive.

With tons of jokes and references to all of your favorite 1980's music, films, and pop-culture icons - Mixtape Massacre will have you laughing while you're slashing!

link.value: Mixtape Massacre: The Black Masque Expansion

item.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Take, a company for domestic engineering.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Haim & Haus, a company for components.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Trafo Baden, a hotel and conference center in Germany.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the public utility company Aue, Germany

Fleet Wharfside is a standalone card game based on Fleet and Fleet: Arctic Bounty. Players compete to complete contracts by selecting contracts from the Market and by collecting fish from their fleet at the wharfside. It's what happens when the fleet comes home!

Tales of the bountiful harvest at Ridback Bay have traveled far, attracting merchants to the local wharfside who wish to pay handsomely for your haul. A successful fisherman’s day is not done with the catch; keen business decisions will determine if your fleet has amassed a rich profit! Merchants have offered generous contracts for the catch, but which offer the greatest benefits? Choose and complete the most lucrative contracts and reap your reward!

In Fleet Wharfside, players fulfill Contracts from local Ridback Bay businesses. Each turn, players will either collect fish from their fleet at the wharfs (by taking cards) or choose to purchase a Contract from the Market. Contracts provide a bonus while in play, but once they are completed the bonus goes away too! The player who collects the most VP from Contracts, Trophies, King Crab, final Goods, and their Captain Bonus wins the game!

Fleet Wharfside is game #8 of the E-G-G Series!

Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of GdaÅ„sk , a city in Poland.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Canterbury, in the United Kingdom.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Newport, in the United Kingdom.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Cheltenham, in the United Kingdom.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Lincoln, in the United Kingdom.

In times of extreme uncertainty, one may call upon the power of Selectinomicon and hope that indecision is the only thing consumed.

Selectinomicon is a collaborative selection metagame which allows a group to come to consensus on a game by voting for various characteristics of games such as theme, mechanisms, weight, and length.

Choose your starting guppy, then use an all-new experience point-based drafting system to buy upgraded bodies and all manner of new parts for your guppy. Quickly adapt it to become the most powerful master fish in the sea with any combination of aquatic bodies and parts you can mash up, battling the other master fish to the death along the way for there can be only one master fish in this ocean.

A.D.A.P.T. is a card game for 2-3 players that usually plays in 20-30 minutes, comes with three full sets of polyhedral dice (3d4s, 3d6s, 3d8s, 6d10s, 3d12s, & 3d20s), and proudly bears a very unique theme. Lightweight, light hearted, and entirely unique — we're certain you've never played anything like it before.

Will your Dolphin, with the armored scales of an Arampaima, the mouth of a giant Sea Bass, the bioelectricity of an Eel, and the tail of a Thresher Shark prove victorious by ramming other fish with its lethal Swordfish horn? Will your Sailfish, with a Clownfish Tail, poisonous Lionfish pectoral fins, and Anglerfish Light Node, followed by a school of fish he commands, be the last Master Fish alive? Or will your Great White Shark, with the spiked skin of a Puffer Fish, over-sized brain, and regenerating heart be the last fish swimming by leaping from the water with its Flying Fish wings for a diving sneak attack? The possibilities are endless!

With Octo, Fantasy, Reptile, Guppy, and Mech expansions also available, there's no reason that your Giant Squid with the wings of a Pegasus and claws of a dragon can't claim victory through use of torpedoes from inside its tortoise shell. Each time you upgrade your fish's body or add new parts, it becomes more powerful, lives longer, and gains new special abilities!

Life under the sea just got much more interesting!

item.description:
The board represents a swimming pool, made up of 25 squares. Shuffle the tiles and place them face-down on to the board, one tile per square.

In your turn, roll once with one of the two dice (the other is only needed for the 2nd version of the game). The diced colour shows where you can take a card.

This is very simple: Each of the dice colours can be seen on the board edge. One line of colours runs along the top and one on the side. If you have thrown red, for example, you take any cards, which lies in the range below or beside the red box. If you are lucky enough to roll White, that is a Joker and you are allowed to take any tile from any of the game board squares plus you can take any one tile from an opponent.

You keep your tiles concealed and you lay them face-down in front of you but shhh, no one will know if it has a rubber ring or not. If you roll a colour which is empty of rings, you are out of luck and you don't get a tile.

When the board has no tiles left on it, the game ends. Whoever has the most cards with a ring has won the game.

There is a variant which is intended for slightly older children.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Milton Keynes, a city in the U.K.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the theme Horrible Histories, a series of illustrated history books.

name.value: Alfred the Great: War in the West Country 876AD

item.description:
Mark Sheppard extends his coverage of this famous monarch with his game on Alfred’s decisive 876 campaign. Not only were the Saxon king and his followers contending with more Viking incursions, but with a rebellion among the native Britons, who sought to take advantage of the King’s woes by seeking to carve out their independence amidst the mayhem. Players familiar with the first volume of the series will be able to quickly get into this game. Each copy of Alfred the Great, Volume II is composed of the following:

One 11 by 17 inch hex map
Two sheets of 286 single-sided, un-mounted counters
Three cardstock Battle Boards (one Briton, one Saxon, one Viking)
One Players’ Aid Sheet
8 pages of rules

Board for this game represents a modern city. CPS Ekspres is a company that drives packages to different locations around the city. Packages are represented by counters. The company has six drivers all have the information where to deliver the package. Markers are collected by stopping on marked field next to counter. Each delivered package brings one point. The winner is the player who ends up with the most points.

Figurines (vans) move around the city respecting all traffic rules. The game has an educational character - playing the game, players learn the traffic rules.

There are 22 white cards which are shuffled and laid out as a board. Special plugs are used to hold the cards together. One of these cards is the Start space and all players put their pawn on that card.

There are 40 Piggy Cards. Their background colour determines which family they belong to. There are 4 families of 5 cards (so each family member has two cards.

The Piggy cards are shuffled and each player is dealt 5 cards. The remaining cards are stacked in the middle of the board. The youngest player begins.
The aim is to collect the 5 members of a family first.

Before a player begins to roll, he draws a card from the deck. Then he rolls the die, and moves his pawn. Whichever card he lands on, he must follow the instructions on it. He ends his turn by discarding a card, forming a discard stack.and shall finally again a card beside the stack. Players may never have more than 5 cards in hand at the end of a turn. The play continues in a clockwise direction. Whoever rolls a 6 may roll again.

The card-types that form the board:

A Chair:
All players need to move one place to the left and leave their cards behind. Thus everyone gets a new hand in effect. The sixth card is discarded before this happens.
Single card icon with two arrows pointing to the right:
All players are required to pass a card to the left, without having first seen the card of the right neighbour.
Paw Print:
The player has to imitate an animal of their choice. Only when the other players have guessed which animal it is. Then he may discard a card.
Die:
The player may roll again.
Two Arrows pointing left and right
All players have to change direction of play, clockwise to anti-clockwise and vice versa.
Circle: 
Nothing happens.
Start Card:
All pawns start the game here. Should you land here during play, you get to roll again.
Card Hand Icon
The player draws a card from the player of his choice, and then gives any card from his hand to the chosen player.
Exchange Icon:
Landing here also lets you pick an opponent and exchange a card but this time the two cards are swapped face down.

First to get all 5 members of one family, wins the game.

Zaljubljene podmornice is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players. Board has 3D elements.

Each player has one submarine. There are several paths that are intertwined. Shorter paths have more obstacles that slow down the submarines. The winner is the player whose submarine first gets to the finish line.

Airfix Magazine Guide 15, written in an informal style, as much an exploration of how to create a wargame, and what it simulates, this small book includes all data needed for a detailed, traditional miniatures system, as well as extensive discussion on why the author made the decisions he did in it's creation. Extensive charts & tables cover point-buy options, movement rates with terrain effects, sighting ranges, armour values (with multiple locations per vehicle) and gun penetration, etc.

The chosen figure scale is 1/72 (to include 1/76), while the miniature to real life ration of 1:1 makes this skirmish scale gaming.

Illustrations through the book are pictures of miniatures and wargames in progress. Original price was £1.40!

Svemirski šetaÄi ("Space walkers") is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players. Board has 3D elements.

There are several paths that are intertwined. Shorter paths have more obstacles. The winner is the player who first gets to the finish line.

Balonijada is game for younger players. Each has one figurine. Hot air balloons fly over a bay, while flying, they should to make as many photos of birds, ships, .... In this game the most points gets the last player who reach the finish line. Each photo (counter) also brings one point. The winner is the player who at the end of the game has the most points.

Rude Martians come to the Moon, but they don't respect traffic rules. Space patrol from the Earth comes to charge fines.

Players move figurines and collect counters by stopping on the field next to counter. The winner is the player who collects the most counters.

The game is played rather like Lotto but has the variation of Bongo Cards. When these are revealed they add a feature to the game. For example, a player who was very far behind, could now be the the frontrunner at once and the former leader drops back to 2nd place. There are 10 different Bongo Cards and once used they go out of the game.

The game is played over a pre-set number of rounds. The one with the most matches after that time has won the game.

UliÄna trka (Street race) is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players. Board has 3D elements.

Each player has one car. All cars drive around a city. There are several paths that are intertwined. Shorter paths have more obstacles that slow down the cars. The winner is the player whose plane first gets to the finish line.

Oldtimer race is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players.

Each player has one oldtimer car. All cars drive around the city and collect counters by stopping on field next to it. The winner is the player who collects the most counters.

Skate girl is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players. Board has 3D elements.

Each player has one figurine and move it along paths. There are several paths that are intertwined. Shorter paths have more obstacles. The winner is the player who first gets to the finish line.

We all know that conspiracies are real. They are trying to clone Hitler, role-playing is actually devil worship and the Reptilian overlords are watching our every move! The problem is that for some reason people ignore these obvious facts. That has to change, and quickly before it's too late!

Conspiracy! is a game for two to four players. During the game players reveal conspiracies, each of which grant the player some special power. Additionally, players can work to discredit the insane conspiracies of other players (what nut jobs!) by leaking stories to the tabloid press. Points are scored for the conspiracies left at the end of the round and those that are accepted possibly true by the public double in value.

The game ends when a player crosses one hundred points. The highest score wins.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Four girls want to dance with boys in discotheque. Players move figurines along paths and collect counters by stopping on field next to it.

Can you outmaneuver the other players and control the finish?

Finish Line is a simple game of moving cars from start to finish. Except everyone is moving every car, and everyone is trying to get the cars to finish in a different order.

On a turn, a player can move up to five cars one space, or remove a stop sign from the board. Optionally and in addition, a player can place a stop sign, or use one of a limited number of "shift chips" to move a car, move a stop sign, or draw a new Finish card. The goal for each round is to get as many cars as possible to finish in the order on your Finish card. The goal of the game is to be the first to have 10 cars finish in the order on your card.

The dynamic of Finish Line changes depending on the number of players, so that an effective strategy for a two-player game might be of no help at all in a four-player game. Adaptability is key.

Girls ride rollers through a park and collect flowers. Bouquets are represented by counters. Players collect counters by stopping on field next to counter. The player who collects the most is the winner.

Moto cross is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players. Board has 3D elements.

Players move figurines in direction of paths. There are several paths that are intertwined. Shorter paths have more obstacles that slow them down. The winner is the player who first gets to the finish line.

Watch out, shark! is a very simple game for 2 to 4 players.

Divers have task to take photos of see animals, but they have to be careful of sharks. Players collect counters than represent photos by stopping on field next to it. The player who collects the most is the winner.

"The beach" is simple game for children.

Players move figurines along paths. There are several paths that are intertwined. Players collect counters by stopping on fields next to counter. The winner is the player who ends up with most points (counters).

name.value: The Earth Wars Saga: Galactic War

item.description:
The galaxy is slowly falling into chaos. The UNE and the Akoran Empire are fighting a bitter war over centuries old claims. The Decoran Republic has been stabbed in the back by the Andromedan Empire and the Federation Commonwealth is launching suicidal Crusades in all directions. The Horloth have been drawn into the conflict and the Ilin are close to declaring war on the UNE. With the Adromedans once more at war other races have grown nervous and have mobilized their militaries. The Nan'Tra'Ki are powerless to stop the spread of conflict and war. The fate of an entire race rests in your hands. Who will you fight for?

Galactic War is a star ship combat game set in the Earth Wars Saga universe in the year 3565. The game comes with an history of both the galaxy and humanity. There are 13 pages of rules and five fleets detailing over 100 ships, patrol boats, and fighters.

Reverse Charades flips the charade standard of one person giving clues to a large group on its head by splitting the players (six or more) into two teams, then having all but one person on a team work together to get that one person to guess as many words as possible in sixty seconds. Each guessed word is worth one point; each word spoken or mouthed costs that team a point.

After each player has guessed once, the team with the most points wins.

This version was given out during Tabletop Day 2015 and consists of 51 double-sided cards, a rule card, and 2 cards promoting other USAopoly games. (no box)

Life is tough when you are a mad scientist trying to resurrect the dead.
Body parts are hard to find, your hired help is unreliable, reanimating lifeless corpses makes your electricity bills skyrocket and those nosy police officers just keep showing up...!

Neck-Back-Toe reimplements the classic game of Tic-Tac-Toe as a solo card game. Every round, nine action cards are laid out in a grid. The player chooses one action at a time, but when three actions in one row on the grid have been taken, the round ends.

Dig up the body parts you need, suture them together and give them life! Then sell your "creations" on the black market before the police catch on to your plans. Hurry! Your reputation at the Mad Scientist Seminar is at stake!

name.value: Im Wandel der Zeiten: Das Kartenspiel

item.description:
Technology is a double-edged sword.

We have grown accustomed to the comforts of civilization, but at the same time we are always creating bigger bloodier methods of destruction.

Will you focus on civil developments to speed up production, or will you build powerful armies to lay waste to your enemies? 
Do you build wonders that leaves a permanent heritage for mankind, or do you want to seize it from those who are not worthy?

Guns & Steel combines the variety of hand building with a unique card flipping mechanism, and enables 2-4 players to compete throughout the ages, struggling to build the greatest empire of the world.

Enjoy a tightly packed strategy game that will force you to make challenging decisions on every turn, and experience the rise & fall of nations in just an hour's time.


Turn Overview


 Resource Phase
 Play a card face-down as a resource card.
 
 Development Phase
 Play a card face-up as a development card.
 
 Purchase Phase
 May buy one card from supply.
 
 End of Turn Phase
 0 or 1 card in hand: 
 Check if you can gain a wonder.
 Retrieve cards to hand.
 
 2 or more cards in hand: Do nothing.
 


Game ends when all wonders are taken, or when all Space age cards have been bought.
The player with most VP on their cards win the game.

link.value: Im Wandel der Zeiten: Das Kartenspiel

item.description:
MesterQuiz is a Norwegian quiz game for 2 to 6 players or teams.
From a total of 16 different categories, each player selects nine categories during the game.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of the city of Béziers, in France.

name.value: À la découverte du corps humain

item.description:
During this game, you will learn about the human body: the operation of the ear, the causes of muscle pain, the different teeth, ...

The teacher (= tiptoi pen) asks you to choose one of the 14 childrens in her class, they'll ask something and she will explain it. Afterwards, she will give you some excercises to learn about the human body. 
F.e. you'll have to find the listed tooth or you have to represent a certain feeling which the other players will have to guess. Each time, you'll be doing other excercises and you'll get 1 or 2 points, depending on how good you did this game. Sometimes you'll be doing these tests by yourself, other things should be done by all players. After a few rounds, the teacher will announce how many points you scored and who won the game!

This game works with the tiptoi-pen and can't be played without it.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
LEXI Card Game is a new word game. There are 55 cards in one deck of LEXI Card Game. There are 52 letter cards; the number of each letter of the alphabet in the deck is according to the frequency of usage for each letter in the English language. There are two WILD cards which may be substituted for any letter of the alphabet. There is one (shortened) Rules/Score card.

At the beginning of the game, the players set a goal of whatever score to be reached to win. (The winning score may be 100, 200, 500, etc.) Every player takes turns dealing. All players get nine cards each at the beginning of the game. One card is flipped open next to the deck, and both are placed at the center of play. The first player draws from either the deck or the opened card, but not both. He may lay down one or more words to be scored at the end of the round; he does not have to lay down any words. When this player is done, he discards one card. Play moves to the next player. All players will take turns playing. When it is a player's turn, he either draws one card from the deck or pick up card(s) from the open discarded pile. If the player draws from the discarded pile, he has to pick up all the cards from the card he wants to the latest discarded one and take it (or them) into his hand. This player has to play the bottom (oldest discarded) card he picks up and spell a word with it. He can, but does not have to spell words with the rest of the letter cards he picks up. When this player is done laying down words in front of him, he must discard one card. A player may add to an existing word he has laid down in a previous turn--by adding a prefix or a suffix--to form a longer word. For example: A player has laid down "ALL" in one turn, and has "E", "R" in his hand. In a subsequent turn, he picks up "T". This player may add to the existing word, "ALL" and form "TALLER". A player may only play and add to his own words and no one else's. For words to count toward a score, the words must be laid down in front of the player during his turn. If the words are not laid down when the round ends, those letters (forming a word) left in a player's hand will not count toward scoring. Moreover, one (1) point will be deducted for every letter left in a player's hand. All players must have taken at least one turn to spell words before the round may be ended. Only the player whose turn it is may end the round. To end a round, a player must use all his cards to spell one or more words, except one which must be discarded. Scores are added up according to the Summation principle:

1 letter word = 1 point; 2 letter words = 1+2= 2 points; 3 letter words = 1+2+3= 6 points; 4 letter words = 1+2+3+4= 10 points; 5 letter words = 1+2+3+4+5= 15 points; 6 letter words = 1+2+3+4+5+6 =21 points, etc.

The players play a new round and add up the scores. Rounds are played until the set score is reached. The first player to reach the set score wins.

So, you're one of the cats in the back yard and the birds out there are all yours! All you have to do is play your cards right and best those other cats!

The cats all start with the same cards: 1 Catch, 2 Stalk, 1 Play, 1 Steal, 1 Taunt, and 1 Eat. No luck of the draw here, it's entirely up to you! Get as many enjoyment points as possible and win the game! Be clever and anticipate what the others will do so that you can claim victory. Each player will target another cat and a location where a bird is hanging out. They will then select their actions for the 2 rounds of action. All of the cards are revealed simultaneously, they get resolved and when the smoke clears, some cats may have birds and some may not.

The birds will hang out at the bird bath, in the grass, on the fence or in the trees. The bigger birds will need to be stalked before catching them and you will have to time everything just right. Once you do catch your bird you will have a choice to either press your luck and play with the bird to double its enjoyment point value or to just eat it. The longer you play with it the greater the chance of it being stolen by another cat.

Taunt cards allow other cats to distract you and cancel your actions, nothing is safe in this back yard!
